items.title: Bovino to leave Minneapolis as Trump reshuffles immigration operation
items.standfirst: Border Patrol commander Gregory Bovino – the US official behind President Donald Trump's aggressive immigration enforcement operations – is expected to leave Minneapolis on Tuesday after Saturday's fatal shooting of ICU nurse Alex Pretty ignited political backlash.
items.content: Border Patrol commander Gregory Bovino – the US official behind President Donald Trump's aggressive immigration enforcement operations – is expected to leave Minneapolis on Tuesday after Saturday's fatal shooting of ICU nurse Alex Pretty ignited political backlash.

items.title: How Minneapolis became ground zero in Trump's immigration crackdown
items.standfirst: The fatal shooting of Alex Pretti by Border Patrol agents has further inflamed tensions in Minneapolis, a city at the center of America's immigration debate in recent months. Here's a look at how it started.
items.content: The fatal shooting of Alex Pretti by Border Patrol agents has further inflamed tensions in Minneapolis, a city at the center of America's immigration debate in recent months. Here's a look at how it started.

items.title: How Minneapolis became ground zero in Trump's immigration crackdown

items.title: Brutal cold temperatures move in as U.S. digs out from deadly winter storm
items.standfirst: The death toll is rising following the massive winter storm that impacted much of the U.S. over the weekend. Now there are new concerns about a cold snap that has millions of Americans under alerts. CBS News' Tom Hanson, Nicole Valdes, Kris Van Cleave and Rob Marciano have more.
items.content: The death toll is rising following the massive winter storm that impacted much of the U.S. over the weekend. Now there are new concerns about a cold snap that has millions of Americans under alerts. CBS News' Tom Hanson, Nicole Valdes, Kris Van Cleave and Rob Marciano have more.

clusters.title: Trump says he will impose new tariffs on South Korea as he criticises delays in trade deal
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump raises US tariffs on South Korea imports to 25%

items.title: Trump says he will impose new tariffs on South Korea as he criticises delays in trade deal
items.standfirst: US president says tariffs on automobiles, lumber and pharmaceuticals will rise to 25%, accusing Seoul of not living up to a trade deal struck last yearDonald Trump has said he is raising tariffs on South Korean goods including automobiles, lumber and pharmaceuticals, accusing the country of not living up to a trade deal struck last year and briefly sending shares in Korean carmakers tumbling.In a post on social media, the US president said the tariffs paid on South Korean exports into America would rise from 15% to 25% because the “Korean Legislature hasn’t enacted our Historic Trade Agreement, which is their prerogative”. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: California governor Gavin Newsom accuses TikTok of suppressing content critical of Trump
items.standfirst: Newsom launched a review of the platform, despite TikTok saying a systems failure was responsible for the issueCalifornia governor Gavin Newsom has accused TikTok of suppressing content critical of president Donald Trump, as he launched a review of the platform’s content moderation practices to determine if they violated state law, even as the platform blamed a systems failure for the issues.The step comes after TikTok’s Chinese owner, ByteDance, said last week it had finalised a deal to set up a majority US-owned joint venture that will secure US data, to avoid a US ban on the short video app used by more than 200 million Americans. Continue reading...

items.title: Gavin Newsom accuses TikTok of suppressing content critical of Trump
items.standfirst: California Governor Gavin Newsom has accused TikTok of suppressing content critical of President Donald Trump and has launched a review into whether the platform’s moderation practices violate state law. The move follows TikTok’s announcement that its Chinese owner, ByteDance, has finalised a deal to avoid a potential US ban.
items.content: California Governor Gavin Newsom has accused TikTok of suppressing content critical of President Donald Trump and has launched a review into whether the platform’s moderation practices violate state law. The move follows TikTok’s announcement that its Chinese owner, ByteDance, has finalised a deal to avoid a potential US ban.

items.title: Video evidence of Alex Pretti’s killing contradicts Trump administration’s account
items.standfirst: 37 year old ICU nurse Alex Pretti was shot and killed in Minneapolis, just week's after Renee Good's fatal shooting in the same city. The Department of Homeland Security claims Pretti was "brandishing" a gun, a "domestic terrorist" and aggressively approaching federal agents...but video evidence directly contradicts the Trump administration's "official" version of events. Vedika Bahl goes through multiple angles of the incident in Truth or Fake.
items.content: 37 year old ICU nurse Alex Pretti was shot and killed in Minneapolis, just week's after Renee Good's fatal shooting in the same city. The Department of Homeland Security claims Pretti was "brandishing" a gun, a "domestic terrorist" and aggressively approaching federal agents...but video evidence directly contradicts the Trump administration's "official" version of events. Vedika Bahl goes through multiple angles of the incident in Truth or Fake.

items.title: Above the law? Outrage over ICE killings in Minneapolis
items.standfirst: 17 days after the shooting death of Renée Good, masked Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis again shooting dead a US citizen, this time 37-year old Alex Pretti. Again, there's video evidence to contradict official narrative that the the victims were acting as domestic terrorists, the race to gather evidence before it can be tainted or destroyed, media echo chambers, and a US president who watches from on high.
items.content: 17 days after the shooting death of Renée Good, masked Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents in Minneapolis again shooting dead a US citizen, this time 37-year old Alex Pretti. Again, there's video evidence to contradict official narrative that the the victims were acting as domestic terrorists, the race to gather evidence before it can be tainted or destroyed, media echo chambers, and a US president who watches from on high.

items.title: Trump dispatches border czar as judge weighs legality of ICE raids in Minnesota
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Monday that border czar Tom Homan is heading to Minnesota as outrage mounts over the killing of US citizen Alex Pretti by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. The move came as a federal judge began hearing arguments on whether the ICE crackdown in Minnesota violates the state's sovereignty and should be halted.
items.content: President Donald Trump said Monday that border czar Tom Homan is heading to Minnesota as outrage mounts over the killing of US citizen Alex Pretti by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents. The move came as a federal judge began hearing arguments on whether the ICE crackdown in Minnesota violates the state's sovereignty and should be halted.

clusters.title: French Lawmakers Vote to Ban Under-15s From Social Media
clusters.neutral_headline: French lawmakers vote to ban social media use by under-15s

items.title: French Lawmakers Vote to Ban Under-15s From Social Media
items.standfirst: French lawmakers passed a bill banning children aged under 15 from accessing social media, the latest government to push forward rules to shield minors from toxic content following the passage of Australia’s landmark legislation last year.
items.content: French lawmakers passed a bill banning children aged under 15 from accessing social media, the latest government to push forward rules to shield minors from toxic content following the passage of Australia’s landmark legislation last year.

items.title: French lawmakers vote to ban social media use by under-15s
items.standfirst: Legislation, which also bans mobile phones in high schools, would make France the second country after Australia to take such a stepFrench lawmakers have passed a bill that would ban social media use by under-15s, a move championed by president Emmanuel Macron as a way to protect children from excessive screen time.The lower national assembly adopted the text by a vote of 130 to 21 in a lengthy overnight session from Monday to Tuesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Legislation, which also bans mobile phones in high schools, would make France the second country after Australia to take such a stepFrench lawmakers have passed a bill that would ban social media use by under-15s, a move championed by president Emmanuel Macron as a way to protect children from excessive screen time.The lower national assembly adopted the text by a vote of 130 to 21 in a lengthy overnight session from Monday to Tuesday. Continue reading...

items.title: France's Macron vows to speed up social media ban for under-15s
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron announced plans to fast-track legislation banning social media use for children under 15, aiming for implementation by September. The move follows Australia's recent ban on under-16s using popular platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube. Macron also supports a ban on mobile phones in schools, with the draft legislation set to be submitted to the French parliament. FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley has the details.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron announced plans to fast-track legislation banning social media use for children under 15, aiming for implementation by September. The move follows Australia's recent ban on under-16s using popular platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube. Macron also supports a ban on mobile phones in schools, with the draft legislation set to be submitted to the French parliament. FRANCE 24's Angela Diffley has the details.

clusters.title: At least 18 people dead as Philippines ferry with 350 onboard sinks
clusters.neutral_headline: At least 18 people dead as Philippines ferry with 350 onboard sinks

items.title: At least 18 people dead as Philippines ferry with 350 onboard sinks
items.standfirst: Rescuers save at least 316 after inter-island ferry sank en route from city of Zamboanga to southern Jolo islandA ferry with more than 350 people onboard sank early on Monday near an island in the southern Philippines, killing at least 18 people, officials said. Rescuers saved hundreds more, while a fleet of coastguard and naval ships searched for those still missing.Coastguard officials said the cargo and passenger ferry apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight. The steel-hulled vessel abruptly tilted to one side and took on water, hurling people into the sea in the darkness, according to a rescued passenger who lost his six-month-old baby. Continue reading...
items.content: Rescuers save at least 316 after inter-island ferry sank en route from city of Zamboanga to southern Jolo islandA ferry with more than 350 people onboard sank early on Monday near an island in the southern Philippines, killing at least 18 people, officials said. Rescuers saved hundreds more, while a fleet of coastguard and naval ships searched for those still missing.Coastguard officials said the cargo and passenger ferry apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight. The steel-hulled vessel abruptly tilted to one side and took on water, hurling people into the sea in the darkness, according to a rescued passenger who lost his six-month-old baby. Continue reading...

items.title: Hundreds rescued after ferry capsizes in the Philippines
items.standfirst: At least 15 people were killed and more are missing after a ferry carrying more than 300 people capsized off the coast of the Philippines. The ferry was sailing with 332 passengers and 27 crew members when it apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight.
items.content: At least 15 people were killed and more are missing after a ferry carrying more than 300 people capsized off the coast of the Philippines. The ferry was sailing with 332 passengers and 27 crew members when it apparently encountered technical problems and sank after midnight.

items.title: At least 15 dead and hundreds rescued after ferry sinks in southern Philippines

items.content: At least 15 people have died after a ferry sank in the southern Philippines overnight.

items.standfirst: Stay present for each move at a time, over and over.
items.content: Stay present for each move at a time, over and over.

items.title: Alex Honnold free solos Taipei 101 skyscraper in live Netflix climb
items.standfirst: US climber takes an hour and half to scale one of Asia’s tallest buildings without ropes or a harnessThe US rock climber Alex Honnold climbed one of Asia’s tallest skyscrapers without ropes or a harness on Sunday, fulfilling an ambition that began more than a decade ago and which he hoped would inspire people to pursue their own challenges because “time is finite”.Honnold, who starred in the 2019 Oscar-winning documentary Free Solo, ascended the 508-metre (1,667ft) Taipei 101 using the skyscraper’s horizontal metal beams to pull himself up with his bare hands. The challenge had originally been scheduled to take place on Saturday but was postponed because of rain. Continue reading...
items.content: US climber takes an hour and half to scale one of Asia’s tallest buildings without ropes or a harnessThe US rock climber Alex Honnold climbed one of Asia’s tallest skyscrapers without ropes or a harness on Sunday, fulfilling an ambition that began more than a decade ago and which he hoped would inspire people to pursue their own challenges because “time is finite”.Honnold, who starred in the 2019 Oscar-winning documentary Free Solo, ascended the 508-metre (1,667ft) Taipei 101 using the skyscraper’s horizontal metal beams to pull himself up with his bare hands. The challenge had originally been scheduled to take place on Saturday but was postponed because of rain. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Project employs technology that can be used to store and release renewable energy using even gentle slopesA hillside “battery” outside Plymouth in Devon has begun generating electricity using a first of a kind hydropower system embedded underground.The pioneering technology means one of the oldest forms of energy storage, hydropower, can be used to store and release renewable energy using even gentle slopes rather than the steep dam walls and mountains that are usually required. items.standfirst: French port’s green energy push, evoking second world war spirit of resilience, is seen as a testing ground for reindustrialisation A new cargo and passenger ferry service directly linking Scotland and France could launch later this year as the port of Dunkirk embarks on a €40bn (£35bn)…
items.content: French port’s green energy push, evoking second world war spirit of resilience, is seen as a testing ground for reindustrialisation A new cargo and passenger ferry service directly linking Scotland and France could launch later this year as the port of Dunkirk embarks on a €40bn (£35bn)…

items.title: Scotland-France ferry could relaunch amid £35bn Dunkirk regeneration plan
items.standfirst: French port’s green energy push, evoking second world war spirit of resilience, is seen as a testing ground for reindustrialisationA new cargo and passenger ferry service directly linking Scotland and France could launch later this year as the port of Dunkirk embarks on a €40bn (£35bn) regeneration programme it claims will mirror the second world war resilience for which it is famed.The plans could include a new service between Rosyth in Fife and Dunkirk, eight years after the last freight ferries linked Scotland to mainland Europe, and 16 years after passenger services stopped. Continue reading...
items.content: French port’s green energy push, evoking second world war spirit of resilience, is seen as a testing ground for reindustrialisationA new cargo and passenger ferry service directly linking Scotland and France could launch later this year as the port of Dunkirk embarks on a €40bn (£35bn) regeneration programme it claims will mirror the second world war resilience for which it is famed.The plans could include a new service between Rosyth in Fife and Dunkirk, eight years after the last freight ferries linked Scotland to mainland Europe, and 16 years after passenger services stopped. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Uganda: Battered Barbra Kyagulanyi tells husband Bobi Wine to stay in hiding
clusters.neutral_headline: Uganda's military chief denies army assaulted Bobi Wine's wife

items.title: Uganda: Battered Barbra Kyagulanyi tells husband Bobi Wine to stay in hiding
items.standfirst: Muhoozi Kainerugaba, Uganda's military chief, denied accusations that soldiers had been sent to the home of opposition leader Bobi Wine to beat his wife in posts on X. Wine has been in hiding since disputing the outcome of the mid-January elections that returned President Yoweri Museveni to power for a seventh term. Kainerugaba claims that troops did not raid Wine's home and assault his wife, Barbra, because it is not worth the army's time. Barbra is currently in hospital. She recorded the intruders on her phone and says they forced their way into her home, choked her, mocked her and assaulted her staff, demanding that she tell them where her husband was.
items.content: Muhoozi Kainerugaba, Uganda's military chief, denied accusations that soldiers had been sent to the home of opposition leader Bobi Wine to beat his wife in posts on X. Wine has been in hiding since disputing the outcome of the mid-January elections that returned President Yoweri Museveni to power for a seventh term. Kainerugaba claims that troops did not raid Wine's home and assault his wife, Barbra, because it is not worth the army's time. Barbra is currently in hospital. She recorded the intruders on her phone and says they forced their way into her home, choked her, mocked her and assaulted her staff, demanding that she tell them where her husband was.

items.title: Remains of last Israeli hostage found in Gaza, paving way for next phase of ceasefire
items.standfirst: The remains of the last hostage held in Gaza have been identified, the Israeli military said Monday, ending a more than two-year saga for captives' families in Israel — and paving the way for the second phase of the ceasefire in the war-torn enclave.
items.content: The remains of the last hostage held in Gaza have been identified, the Israeli military said Monday, ending a more than two-year saga for captives' families in Israel — and paving the way for the second phase of the ceasefire in the war-torn enclave.
